.git/hooks/prepare-commit-msg.sample

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 #!/bin/sh
00002 #
00003 # An example hook script to prepare the commit log message.
00004 # Called by "git commit" with the name of the file that has the
00005 # commit message, followed by the description of the commit
00006 # message's source.  The hook's purpose is to edit the commit
00007 # message file.  If the hook fails with a non-zero status,
00008 # the commit is aborted.
00009 #
00010 # To enable this hook, rename this file to "prepare-commit-msg".
00011 
00012 # This hook includes three examples.  The first comments out the
00013 # "Conflicts:" part of a merge commit.
00014 #
00015 # The second includes the output of "git diff --name-status -r"
00016 # into the message, just before the "git status" output.  It is
00017 # commented because it doesn't cope with --amend or with squashed
00018 # commits.
00019 #
00020 # The third example adds a Signed-off-by line to the message, that can
00021 # still be edited.  This is rarely a good idea.
00022 
00023 case "$2,$3" in
00024   merge,)
00025     /usr/bin/perl -i.bak -ne 's/^/# /, s/^# #/#/ if /^Conflicts/ .. /#/; print' "$1" ;;
00026 
00027 # ,|template,)
00028 #   /usr/bin/perl -i.bak -pe '
00029 #      print "\n" . `git diff --cached --name-status -r`
00030 #    if /^#/ && $first++ == 0' "$1" ;;
00031 
00032   *) ;;
00033 esac
00034 
00035 # SOB=$(git var GIT_AUTHOR_IDENT | sed -n 's/^\(.*>\).*$/Signed-off-by: \1/p')
00036 # grep -qs "^$SOB" "$1" || echo "$SOB" >> "$1"
